so what you saw there was a lot of Technology transforming the customer experience and when we're doing anything
at transport what we're trying to do is really to pull two levers to improve the customer experience and reduce our
operational costs because running transport is an expensive exercise and we do it through those principles I just
talked about before now how did we get there you know what was what was our process of working out what
to do and why to do it when Minister Constance became our transport minister
back in 2015 and he looked at the portfolio of transport that was being
invested in one of the things he was really very keen to make sure that was
done right was that anything we do with technology is future proofed and done in the right way so we thought it long
about that about what's the right way to do this how to bring it to life and we looked at a couple of different options
one option was to pick up the phone to a consulting house like a BCG or a McKinsey or one of the four and say what
should we do to put transport at the center of technology at the center of all things transport well actually what
we decided to do instead was we looked at in the startup community in industry and our employees university students
and we looked across that broad spectrum of folks and when actually they've got all the answers
they know what we need to do so what we decided to do instead was to bring everyone together over a couple of days
in 2016 in a program that we call the future transport technology and we asked
all the participants one question if you were the secretary of Transport what would you do to put technology at the
center of transport and for those non-government folks here secretary is
you basically a group chief executive so he asked everyone to imagine that they had that role and what would they do and
in over a couple of days we got them excited about what was possible with some really great speakers talking about
different areas of Technology and in the afternoon we had a big design thinking session with all the participants to
extract all the ideas sitting over the top we had a panel guiding us through it and we
were lucky enough to have David 30 chair it for us and shape what it needed to be
and through the course of 2016 we went and did that program with the same for
university students we ran a entrepreneur hothouse for all our twenty
five thousand plus employees asking them the same question with a million dollar Micro Fund to take forty ideas through
that through the peripheral concept and all of that resulted in the future transport technology roadmap which you

unveils very healthfully he didn't to know too much about public transport but
so basically what all those participants told us was a few things the first thing
is technology itself doesn't matter it's all about how humans engage with technology that drives disruption and we
don't know they don't know which way technology is going to shape and go in the future but broadly speaking there'll
be five customer strategies that we need to have a good think about and four key usage scenarios that work that we need
to be mindful of the first one being my autonomous car is King and this is where there's a future where we're all being
shipped around cities in autonomous pods there's the the next one which is we're all on this together which is all about
active and public transport and making life choice decisions around where we
live work and play around public transport hubs the super commuter which
again was all about this idea of mobility as a service if you've seen that and then why travel so much which
is all about the actual those 30 minute hubs that you've seen talked about in
New South Wales and all that guided five customer facing strategies which you see there on your left and for us one of the
key learnings from everyone was this is good you can see the different
futures ahead of you you can develop up some strategies about what you need to do but the important thing is is once
you accept that you don't know which one of those strategies are going to come to life first what you can then do instead
is focus on what we call no regrets initiatives so these are things that we
should do no matter which way the future looks and in that video before you saw a
lot of them you saw us announcing our smart Innovation Center
and driving my driving part in the pan getting autonomous vehicles out there on

these no regrets initiatives that you see there our intelligent congestion management program the on-demand

development for both the industry and the public sector is this idea about
being comfortable about not knowing which way the future is that that's okay and what you need to do instead is focus
on those no regrets initiatives to position yourself so that no matter which way the future goes you're ready

is you know we created an ecosystem of third-party apps out there but what we
wanted to do with local travel was to take what we know about the opal card and enhance it with journey planning and
provide an enhanced customer experience to our customers around that so we
introduced a lot of features into Opel travel that were originally designed from customers with accessibility needs
so for instance if you do a journey playing with Opel travel and you press GO when you're three stops away it will
send you a notification on your phone to say you're coming up to your destination two stops away it will send you another
one then one stop in to your destination it will then say time to get off the service now we put in features like that
for customers with accessibility needs but actually if you've been on the train and you've fallen asleep like me what
you'll see is that you get this notification you kind of wake up and you go right time to get off we've also
integrated into here real time disruption notifications so that when your service is disrupted you get a
notification about it you click on the link and then we'll serve to you a new journey plan based on the conditions of
the network to get you to where you need to go so this is in the spirit of reuse
now the other thing that we decided to do was when we looked at Opel and we
think about the customer value chain of how they use public transport this planned book pay travel provide feedback
and rinse and repeat it was really really hard to open up anything around
Opel so what we decided to do instead but and we knew from open data that opening up these platforms only creates

the spirit of of everything that you've probably heard here today about minimum viable product customer trial proving
our proof of concepts and all that sort of good stuff the contactless payments program was all of that we started in
July 2017 on a single ferry going from Manley to circular key it was the most basic of the
propositions if anyone's done mainly the circular key its tap on only there's no tap on
off so the logic was really easy to build it was one fair there's no different fair bands that we needed to
worry about and we did it with one card provider which was MasterCard we then
expanded that MVP into light rail and ferries so all of light rail all of
fairies so we introduced tap on and tap off capability which in opal fare rules
there's a lot of complexity behind the logic of the fares so just working
through that was the right way to go about it em and then later on that year
which was November last year we rolled it out across all 308 train stations in
the Sidney greater Sydney network and everywhere from Newcastle denno kiama
announcer at the Bathurst and what we've done there is we introduced the day
capping features of opal we introduced the fare table to be the same as the
opal cart and then about three weeks ago we then made the last part of the

buses now once we've done that and we've targeted that by the end of September we
have inadvertently created Australia's largest contactless payments network so

ring a normal card however the form factor innovates in the future we're out
